column5: do they use pure salt on the roads in Quebec like they do in Ontario,any body know ,i was always told to be aware not to buy a care from Ontario becuase of the salt

That is very true! The salt destroys the bodies of cars. I now in southern Quebec, anywhere around Montreal they also use salt. They use more sand further west (like Alberta), but have now started using some salt as well. If the sand is low quality, then it gets full of small rocks, and windshield replacements become more of a problem. In northwestern Ontario most places use sand. NWO Fishing Bum

[font color=green size=3][b]My daughter bought a car that the dealership purchased at a midwest auction, it was only a year old then. The hood rusted thru in the corners after 1 more year and the underside was coated with rust. A carfax revealed the original owner was from Quebec. Wish'in I was fish'in on Wabby

I contend that anyone, whether from Ontario or Quebec, who is prepared to look after their vehicles, doesn't have to be overly concerned about salt. I'm still driving a 1991 Ford Explorer, original paint, and there is very little rust on my vehicle. Mind you, it gets an oil based rust inhibitor treatment every fall.
retire, i agree. i lived in maryland for 20 years. they salt when snow or ice is in the forecast. never seen anything like it. never had a problem. gotta run it thru a car wash once in a while.
You have to salt the roads here...no choice. We have the worlds second busiest hiway in Toronto and it has to be clear of snow to prevent accidents.
